image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The RBA has lifted the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points in November, taking the rate to 4.35 per cent, while the Australian share market is trading lower. Follow live.

title.children: RBA lifts interest rates to 12-year high of 4.35pc, WeWork files for bankruptcy in US, ASX slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've got questions about today's interest rates decision (or anything else economy-related) that you've been wanting to ask, now's your time to do so. Our colleague, business reporter Gareth Hutchens is ready and waiting to help you make sense of what today's decision means for households, the economy, and where the RBA might go from here. Send through your questions using the big blue button at the top of the blog, and they'll be answered shortly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What do you want to know about today's interest rate decision?

children.content: If you've got questions about today's interest rates decision (or anything else economy-related) that you've been wanting to ask, now's your time to do so.
Our colleague,
business reporter Gareth Hutchens
is ready and waiting to help you make sense of what today's decision means for households, the economy, and where the RBA might go from here.
Send through your questions using the big blue button at the top of the blog, and they'll be answered shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's some of the rationale from RBA governor Michele Bullock's statement: Inflation in Australia has passed its peak but is still too high and is proving more persistent than expected a few months ago. The latest reading on CPI inflation indicates that while goods price inflation has eased further, the prices of many services are continuing to rise briskly. While the central forecast is for CPI inflation to continue to decline, progress looks to be slower than earlier expected. CPI inflation is now expected to be around 3.5 per cent by the end of 2024 and at the top of the target range of 2 to 3 per cent by the end of 2025. The Board judged an increase in interest rates was warranted today to be more assured that inflation would return to target in a reasonable timeframe. Ms Bullock also said the RBA may need to increase rates further, however "whether further tightening of monetary policy is required to ensure that inflation returns to target in a reasonable timeframe will depend upon the data and the evolving assessment of risks ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why did the RBA lift interest rates in November?

While the central forecast is for CPI inflation to continue to decline, progress looks to be slower than earlier expected.

cent by the end of 2024 and at the

will depend upon the data and the evolving assessment of risks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The RBA has lifted the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 4.35% at its November meeting. It's the 13th rate rise in 19 months, and means the cash rate is now the highest it's been since November 2011. For more, my colleague Michael Janda has you covered:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: RBA lifts cash rate to 4.35 per cent

featuredLink.title: Reserve Bank raises interest rates, average repayments now up more than 50pc since hikes began

children.content: The RBA has lifted the cash rate by 0.25 percentage points to 4.35% at its November meeting.
It's the 13th rate rise in 19 months, and means the cash rate is now the highest it's been since November 2011.
For more, my colleague
Michael Janda
has you covered:

image.altText: A jockey in red silks, raises his arm in celebration, while on top of his horse with red blinkers on.

items.synopsis: Australia's most famous horserace is next, with legendary jockey Damien Oliver riding his final Melbourne Cup. Follow live.

title.children: All eyes on Flemington as the Melbourne Cup is up next

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 21 - Future History: English-bred horse now one of the Maher/Eustace stable. Has been placed no worse than third in five runs in Australia, but hasn't run beyond 2,520m. Ridden by top English hoop Hollie Doyle. 22 - Interpretation: Another Maher/Eustace entry, this Irish-bred six-year-old earned a spot in the Cup with a win in last week's Bendigo Cup. Failed to finish last year's Cup. 23 - Kalapour: Took the last spot in the Cup field with a win in the Archer Stakes on Derby Day. Irish-bred gelding trained by Kris Lees, will be ridden by apprentice Zac Lloyd. Hasn't run beyond 2,600m. 24 - True Marvel: French-bred horse trained by Matthew Smith at Warwick Farm in Sydney. A true stayer, who has placed in last year's Sydney and Brisbane Cups.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Melbourne Cup horses: 21 - 24

children.content: 21 - Future History: English-bred horse now one of the Maher/Eustace stable. Has been placed no worse than third in five runs in Australia, but hasn't run beyond 2,520m. Ridden by top English hoop Hollie Doyle.
22 - Interpretation: Another Maher/Eustace entry, this Irish-bred six-year-old earned a spot in the Cup with a win in last week's Bendigo Cup. Failed to finish last year's Cup.

23 - Kalapour: Took the last spot in the Cup field with a win in the Archer Stakes on Derby Day. Irish-bred gelding trained by Kris Lees, will be ridden by apprentice Zac Lloyd. Hasn't run beyond 2,600m.
24 - True Marvel: French-bred horse trained by Matthew Smith at Warwick Farm in Sydney. A true stayer, who has placed in last year's Sydney and Brisbane Cups.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 17 - Military Mission: Trained by Gai Waterhouse and Adrian Bott, this Irish import has won two of its last three starts, but another horse who has not raced over more than 2,400m. Ridden by Rachel King. 18 - Serpentine: The other Waterhouse/Bott entry in the Cup is a former English Derby winner at Epsom, but he was 20th in last year's Cup and has only won once since coming to Australia. 2020 Cup winner Jye McNeil is on board. 19 - Virtuous Circle: NZ-bred stallion trained in Victoria by Liam Howley and ridden by Craig Newitt. Eighth in the Geelong Cup, his only two wins have come over 1,500m. 20 - More Felons: This lightweight Irish import (formerly known as Scriptwriter) has won over hurdles at Cheltenham like Vauban. A flashing fifth in the Geelong Cup, he is ridden by star jockey Jamie Kah.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Melbourne Cup horses: 17 - 20

children.content: 17 - Military Mission: Trained by Gai Waterhouse and Adrian Bott, this Irish import has won two of its last three starts, but another horse who has not raced over more than 2,400m. Ridden by Rachel King.

18 - Serpentine: The other Waterhouse/Bott entry in the Cup is a former English Derby winner at Epsom, but he was 20th in last year's Cup and has only won once since coming to Australia. 2020 Cup winner Jye McNeil is on board.
19 - Virtuous Circle: NZ-bred stallion trained in Victoria by Liam Howley and ridden by Craig Newitt. Eighth in the Geelong Cup, his only two wins have come over 1,500m.

20 - More Felons: This lightweight Irish import (formerly known as Scriptwriter) has won over hurdles at Cheltenham like Vauban. A flashing fifth in the Geelong Cup, he is ridden by star jockey Jamie Kah.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 13 - Okita Soushi: After the withdrawal of Valiant King on Friday, this is the only entry from Irish trainer Joseph O'Brien, who has two Cup wins. A winner over 3,200m, the six-year-old will be ridden by star apprentice Dylan Gibbons. 14 - Sheraz: A French import racing for Chris Waller, this seven-year-old gelding has Beau Mertens on board. He has had four runs at 3,000 - 3,200m for one win and three seconds. 15 - Lastotchka: Lightly-raced French import now trained by Mick Price and Micheal Kent - this is the only mare in the race, and she has Cup-winning jockey Craig Williams on board. 16 - Magical Lagoon: Another import running for Chris Waller, this mare from Ireland has won the Irish Oaks (over 2,400m) and been second over 3,200m at Goodwood, but her best run in Australia has been sixth in the Geelong Cup.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Melbourne Cup horses: 13 - 16

children.content: 13 - Okita Soushi: After the withdrawal of Valiant King on Friday, this is the only entry from Irish trainer Joseph O'Brien, who has two Cup wins. A winner over 3,200m, the six-year-old will be ridden by star apprentice Dylan Gibbons.
14 - Sheraz: A French import racing for Chris Waller, this seven-year-old gelding has Beau Mertens on board. He has had four runs at 3,000 - 3,200m for one win and three seconds.
15 - Lastotchka: Lightly-raced French import now trained by Mick Price and Micheal Kent - this is the only mare in the race, and she has Cup-winning jockey Craig Williams on board.

16 - Magical Lagoon: Another import running for Chris Waller, this mare from Ireland has won the Irish Oaks (over 2,400m) and been second over 3,200m at Goodwood, but her best run in Australia has been sixth in the Geelong Cup.

image.altText: A Palestinian wounded in Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip is brought to a hospital.

items.synopsis: Israel says it would consider "tactical little pauses" in fighting to allow for aid and the release of hostages, but has rejected calls for a ceasefire, while Israel's neighbour Jordan says "all options" are on the table. Follow live.

title.children: Israel open to 'tactical little pauses' in Gaza assault for aid, release of hostages

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) has appealed to international health and relief organisations to "provide essential aid and supplies" to northern Gaza. The fuel reserves for Al Quds Hospital 's power generator are anticipated to run out within 48 hours, the organisation added in a statement posted on X. It said Israel's blockade on Gaza was posing "an eminent threat" to the operation of ambulances, emergency services, hospitals and the relief of displaced individuals by preventing essential resources from entering. "The hospital's fuel reserves will run out within 48 hours, and life-saving equipment, neonatal incubators, and intensive care units will cease to function", it said. "Additionally, there is a severe shortage of medical supplies, medicines and a significant lack of food and drinking water for medical staff, patients, and the wounded." It said more than 14,000 displaced people had been residing within the hospital's premises for more than three weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian Red Crescent Society appeals for urgent international aid for hospitals

children.content: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society
(PRCS) has appealed to international health and relief organisations to "provide essential aid and supplies" to northern Gaza.
The fuel reserves for
Al Quds Hospital
's power generator are anticipated to run out within 48 hours, the organisation added in a statement posted on X.

It said Israel's blockade on Gaza was posing "an eminent threat" to the operation of ambulances, emergency services, hospitals and the relief of displaced individuals by preventing essential resources from entering.
"The hospital's fuel reserves will run out within 48 hours, and life-saving equipment, neonatal incubators, and intensive care units will cease to function", it said.
"Additionally, there is a severe shortage of medical supplies, medicines and a significant lack of food and drinking water for medical staff, patients, and the wounded."
It said more than 14,000 displaced people had been residing within the hospital's premises for more than three weeks.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: About 100 pro-Palestinian protesters have been disrupting traffic at an Ascot Vale intersection as thousands of punters continue to make their way to Flemington Racecourse ahead of the running of the Cup, according to police. Police say the protesters arrived about 11am at the Epsom Road, Ascot Vale Road and Racecourse Road roundabout and caused traffic disruptions. Two protesters, including a woman who climbed onto the roof of a white van and refused to get down, were pepper-sprayed and arrested, according to police. Police say the incident remains ongoing, with about 80 protesters at the scene, and they have arranged for the van to be towed away.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pro-Palestinian protesters disrupt traffic near Melbourne Cup

children.content: About 100 pro-Palestinian protesters have been disrupting traffic at an Ascot Vale intersection as thousands of punters continue to make their way to Flemington Racecourse ahead of the running of the Cup, according to police.
Police say the protesters arrived about 11am at the Epsom Road, Ascot Vale Road and Racecourse Road roundabout and caused traffic disruptions.

children.content: Police say they arrested two protesters at a roundabout near the Flemington Racecourse.
(AAP: Con Chronis)
Two protesters, including a woman who climbed onto the roof of a white van and refused to get down, were pepper-sprayed and arrested, according to police.
Police say the incident remains ongoing, with about 80 protesters at the scene, and they have arranged for the van to be towed away.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says that Israel would consider "tactical little pauses" in the fighting in Gaza to facilitate the entry of humanitarian aid or allow the exit of hostages held by Hamas militants. But the Israeli leader reiterated his country's rejection of a ceasefire without the release of all people being held captive in the Hamas-ruled Palestinian enclave. Mr Netanyahu made the comments in an interview with the US ABC News. "Well, there'll be no ceasefire, no general ceasefire in Gaza without the release of our hostages," he said. "As far as tactical little pauses — an hour here, an hour there — we've had them before. "I suppose we'll check the circumstances, in order to enable goods, humanitarian goods, to come in, or our hostages, individual hostages, to leave." He was also asked who should govern Gaza after fighting is over. "I think Israel will for an indefinite period ... have the overall security responsibility because we've seen what happens when we don't have that security responsibility," he said. Both Israel and Hamas have rebuffed mounting international pressure for a ceasefire. Israel says Hamas should release the hostages first; Hamas says it will not free them or stop fighting while Gaza is under assault. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel open to 'little pauses' in Gaza fighting, Netanyahu says

children.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says that Israel would consider "tactical little pauses" in the fighting in Gaza to facilitate the entry of humanitarian aid or allow the exit of hostages held by Hamas militants.
But the Israeli leader reiterated his country's rejection of a ceasefire without the release of all people being held captive in the Hamas-ruled Palestinian enclave.
Mr Netanyahu made the comments in an interview with the US ABC News.
"Well, there'll be no ceasefire, no general ceasefire in Gaza without the release of our hostages," he said.
"As far as tactical little pauses — an hour here, an hour there — we've had them before.
"I suppose we'll check the circumstances, in order to enable goods, humanitarian goods, to come in, or our hostages, individual hostages, to leave."
